Pork and Duck Egg Congee

Serves 2 Source of Recipe Ben 0’Donoghue

Preparation Time Over 1 hr

Cooking Time Over 2 hrs

Ingredients
  • 125g/4oz Thai fragrant long grain rice
  • 15ml/1tbsp sunflower oil
  • 1tsp salt
  • 1½L/2½pt fresh chicken stock
  • 3 duck eggs
  • 150ml/¼pt soy sauce plus extra to serve
  • 2 star anise
  • 2tbsp green gunpowder tea
  • 1tbsp Szechwun pepper
  • 1tsp salt
  • 350g/12oz pork fillet
  • 5ml/1tsp vegetable oil
To serve:
  • 2 spring onions, sliced very thinly handful of prawn crackers ground white pepper
Method

  1. Wash the long grain rice in several changes of water and soak overnight in 750ml/1¼pt of water with the oil and salt. Drain well the next day.

  2. Bring the chicken stock to the boil in a saucepan and add the soaked rice. Bring to the boil and simmer for 2 hours until it breaks down. Check seasoning and keep warm.

  3. While this is cooking, cook the duck eggs. Put them into cold salted water, bring to the boil and cook for 8 minutes. Refresh in cold water. Roll until shell is cracked, but not coming off.

  4. Place the eggs back in the pan. Add the soy and enough water to cover. Add the star anise and black tea and simmer the duck eggs for a further 1 hour. Leave to cool in the liquid.

  5. Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6. In a pestle and mortar crush the Szechwun pepper and salt. Roll the pork fillet in the mixture to coat. Heat the oil in a small ovenproof frying pan and seal the pork quickly, without colouring. Transfer to the oven and roast for approximately 10 minutes. Allow to rest for a few minutes and slice thinly.

  6. To finish, peel the eggs and cut them in half. Carefully stir them through the congee with the sliced pork. Heat the mixture through gently for a few minutes. Spoon into serving bowls and top with the spring onions and crumbled prawn crackers. Drizzle the soy over and a grinding of white pepper.

Published: July 22 2012
